Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the mother should purchase it
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story:
I stare at my phone, the screen lighting up with a message from Mark: “Can’t wait for our night together. Just us.” My heart aches a little. We’ve barely seen each other lately, and tomorrow he leaves for a week. I want to make tonight special, just the two of us, no distractions. But then I hear my son’s voice from the living room, excitedly reminding me, “Mom, you promised we’d get the Nintendo today!” He’s been saving up, counting the days, and I know how much this means to him. But the price tag is steep, and I’ve been worrying about bills all month. I promised him, though. I promised. 

I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in. My son’s hopeful eyes, Mark’s anticipation, my own exhaustion. I want to be the mom who keeps her word, who makes her child’s dreams come true. I want to be the girlfriend who shows up, who makes our rare time together count. But I can’t be in two places at once, and I can’t stretch the money any further. My chest tightens as I try to figure out who needs me more tonight.
